title: How to Stain Floors

steps.headline: Repair obvious defects such as nail holes, cracks or gouges in the floor using a wood putty or filler.
Sand floor in direction of grain of the wood.
steps.description: Use a floor sanding machine and edge sander or sand by hand. If sanding by hand, use 3 different grits of sandpaper, 30, 60 and 80. Vacuum floor between each sanding and when finished.

steps.headline: Clean floor with mineral spirits and a soft cotton cloth to pick up any remaining dust or dirt.
Apply base coat of wood conditioner around perimeter of room using a 4 inch (10.16 centimeters) paintbrush.
Use a synthetic applicator to spread conditioner across the middle of the floor; allow to dry two hours.
Test stain on small area of floor.
Apply stain, according to label directions, with a brush or rag, working the stain into the wood.
steps.description: Your final stroke should always be in the same direction as the wood's grain.

steps.headline: Let stain penetrate according to the label's directions; remove excess with a rag, ensuring again that you wipe in the direction of the grain.
steps.description: If you want a darker color, apply second coat in same manner. Allow to dry until stain is no longer tacky.

steps.headline: Apply top coat of water-based polyurethane with a clean paintbrush and floor finish applicator.
steps.description: This helps to protect and preserve the wood. Allow to dry two hours; apply second coat.

Use a floor sanding machine and edge sander or sand by hand. If sanding by hand, use 3 different grits of sandpaper, 30, 60 and 80. Vacuum floor between each sanding and when finished. Clean floor with mineral spirits and a soft cotton cloth to pick up any remaining dust or dirt.  Apply base coat of wood conditioner around perimeter of room using a 4 inch (10.16 centimeters) paintbrush.  Use a synthetic applicator to spread conditioner across the middle of the floor; allow to dry two hours.  Test stain on small area of floor.  Apply stain, according to label directions, with a brush or rag, working the stain into the wood. Your final stroke should always be in the same direction as the wood's grain. Let stain penetrate according to the label's directions; remove excess with a rag, ensuring again that you wipe in the direction of the grain. If you want a darker color, apply second coat in same manner. Allow to dry until stain is no longer tacky. Apply top coat of water-based polyurethane with a clean paintbrush and floor finish applicator. This helps to protect and preserve the wood. Allow to dry two hours; apply second coat.
